title: Associate Program Officer Interview

Interview Questions: They asked questions about my writing samples which were based on my doctoral research.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences in Jun 2020
Interview Descriptions:
Really dry interview process with even less enthusiastic interviewers and staff. The first was an interview screen with a recruiter - a basic 15-20 minute call where you walk through your resume and discuss why you want to work at NAS. The questions were pretty standard. One question which I didn't expect was when the interviewer asked me what makes me different from the other candidates as I have the same qualifications as every other person who has applied..the wording of this question honestly seemed a bit rude. The interview ended with salary discussion on what you expect to be paid. 

The second interview was with the Senior Program Officer and a program assistant and/or consultant. Note, I did two different interviews for two departments on the same week so the panel interviewers varied but normally consisted of a panel interview with 2-4 people. I found this process to be a bit off as the "lower ranking" people seemed to all turn on their videos for the zoom interview but the "high ranking" SPO decided not to turn on their video for both of their interviews. It was really awkward having my video turned on and talking to the other staff members but not being able to see the highest ranking SPO during the conversation. It made it really difficult to detect facial cues and resulting in a lot of awkward silences. 

I was invited to a third interview with their Executive Director. I declined at this point because I was offered a position at another organization and decided to accept that. 

Overall, this interview process was of and felt like I was just a number in a sea of candidates. It was not personal, the staff/interviewers did not try to get to know me and I really didn't have the opportunity to get to know staff members and company culture. I felt pretty rushed during the allocated 1 hour interview phase, where both my interviews ended in 40 minutes because it seemed like the SPO had more important things to do. This was one of the stiffest interviews I have been on - and felt more like a transaction than a conversation. Very mechanical and impersonal. Makes me wonder what the work culture is actually like there.
Interview Questions:
Why the National Academies? 
Make sure to know the specific research conducted within the department you are working for. They are looking for a perfect match on people who have a good background and experience in the specific factors that they are researching. 

Tell me about yourself/background. 
What experience do you have on research topic X? 
Are you familiar with personality tests and what did you receive? 
How do you deal with constructive feedback?
What is your "superpower" and what is something that you absolutely cannot do? 
How do you deal with a difficult co-worker or manager?

title: Associate Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences
Interview Descriptions: I talked with various members of the team and learned about the process as well as the skills needed to succeed at the NAS.  I learned about the community, funding, and workflow.
Interview Questions: How did you deal with a difficult person?

title: Senior Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences (Washington, DC) in Feb 2020
Interview Descriptions:
Feb 12 - Applied online 
Feb 14 - Recruiter contacted me and proceeded to discuss the position within a week. They asked me what makes me stand out from all the other candidates. I thought that it was an unnecessary question because they have my resume! Also, this question is subjective, but I gave an objective answer by reiterating the job qualifications and my resume. We also discussed salary, and the recruiter made it clear that is it not negotiable, but they wanted to prepare me I suppose in case we proceeded further. 
Feb 21 - Met with the director and a senior program officer. They were both friendly. It was more of a discussion. I prepared tremendously for this position. I gave them hard copies of examples of my own work, including publications, manuals, and guidelines that I developed from my previous jobs. I also gave them hard copies of the material on what I knew about NAS and their productivity, and I had questions on their evaluation of performance by giving them specific examples. In addition, I gave them a paper on what studies I would conduct if I was selected as a Senior Program Officer, and who to contact to work with other people in the field. I gave the about 5 project proposals and wrote them with references. Towards the end of the interview, the director was impressed. In fact, he said that my work is outstanding and it he thought it was a really great interview. Personally, I thought that it was a great interview too! I over prepared and worked really hard, and it showed. This interview lasted over the time limit because the director and I had many questions to ask each other. 
March 11 - No updated on my application so I emailed the recruiter for the status. They said that they were still interviewing more candidates. 
July 7 - I was informed that the job was CANCELED, and that they ceased recruiting efforts for that job!  

Overall, I was extremely positive and energetic during the interview. I showed a lot of ambition and enthusiasm than any normal person! I am also a very young person applying for the Senior Program Officer position. IMO, I think all these things could have been the reason why I wasn't selected. This is a very flat organization and people have worked there many years. It not uncommon for people to feel complacent. When I came into the building, I can already sense the dreary mood. However, I felt more compelled to get a job here despite the negative reviews. I felt that I could have been the person to balance out the potential team/organization with my energy. Perhaps, I wasn't selected because it could have been a cultural mis-match. Anyways, if you get an interview, take it! I still believe that it was a tremendous honor to even get an interview at the National Academy of Sciences! Though, I am confident that they overlooked a high qualified candidate.
Interview Questions: Why NAS? What makes you stand out? How well do you work with people?

title: Senior Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences in Jan 2020
Interview Descriptions: The interview had very basic questions that mostly focused on personality. These type of recommendations are somewhat common practice in any field, but it seemed a bit too family-like. I was actually relieved that I did not get the offer which let me know this would not be the right environment for me.

Q: They provided an example topic and asked, "What areas of expertise would you seek to build your panel?"

Q. How would you deal with a panel member that was making it difficult to run the meeting?

title: Senior Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences (Washington, DC) in Dec 2018
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted for a phone screen several weeks after applying for the position. I was then asked to come in for an in-person interview to meet with two potential colleagues and the overall director of the program. The meet and greet with the potential colleagues went fine, pretty basic Q&A and they seemed nice. The meeting with the director was ridiculous. He asked me how I felt about not having experience with some aspects of the job, which were not listed on the job description, and seemed to expect me to justify why I was present at the interview. It was very awkwardly handled and not a position that any applicant should have to be put in. If the experience listed on a resume is not sufficient for the position then there is no need to bring the candidate in for an interview. It was clear when I walked out of the final meeting that they were looking for someone with more specialized experience than was listed in the job description and overall I felt that they wasted both my time and theirs - simply ridiculous.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Assistant Interview

title: Media Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: Everyone I met was very friendly, but there was a lack of professionalism in the process. I met with the head of the department, three higher-ups, the other media assistant, and the HR representative. The actual interview was good and I enjoyed all the conversations. After the interview, I received an email from the HR rep asking me back for another interview and listing possible times. After I had responded with the time that worked, he recalled the email and said he appreciated my interest, but that they were still deliberating and that I was premature in responding. Except that I had gotten an email about a second interview that listed dates, so of course I responded to it. Weeks went by and I never heard back, and I didn't get a response until I followed up. When I did, it was a canned response. I can't help but wonder if the email confusion was a part of the reason I didn't get the position, which would suck because it was a goof on the part of the HR rep who didn't own up to it. Plus, I think it's super rude not to let someone know who has taken two hours of their time to interview in person that they didn't get the job. At least give them closure.
Interview Questions: No out of the ordinary interview questions.

title: Program Officer Interview

title: Senior Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online last Nov., 
Received Phone Call/Brief Phone Interview 2 weeks later (Know why you're interested in company,etc and be ready to discuss your resume-be prepared, will be asked about salary too), During Phone call scheduled interview in two weeks
1st In Person Interview 2 weeks later, Met with team of department/head person, really friendly group of people, the best interview Ive ever had, I was extremely prepared so that helped tremendously, but the people were really supportive in listening and well intentioned, really tried to get to you, not embarrass you or make the interview hard intentionally which was great, really nice open, laid back atmosphere, great vibe,quiet office, was about 1hr/half long
Received a phone call a couple hours later after 1st interview asking for second interview the following week
Met with the very top person of the dept and brief interview with HR (basically went over resume, etc, not a real interview formally) 1 week later, the very top person was extremely friendly and kind and laid-back. 
Found out about 3 weeks later that I didn't receive position via email with subject line - Status Selection (I almost deleted and thought it was spam). 

Overall took about 2 1/2 months. 

Very long and thorough process, but well worth it. Very nice and kind people. Great atmosphere. The only thing I will say is that the HR recruiter was very abrupt and impersonal and lacked basic social skills and was pushy at times. Didn't seem very racially/ethnically, religiously, etc. diverse. Predominately white men/women organization. Also, seems like the pay is very low period and in comparison to duties. The org is reorganizing and may consolidate a position without increasing pay. HR recruiter appeared extremely inflexible about pay increase, like it was absolutely impossible but benefits seemed pretty good. Also, I would suggest you have some great questions that are innovative and shows you've really researched the company and interviewers(make sure you get everyone's name prior from recruiter).
Interview Questions: If you won the lottery today, what would you do? What is an example of working with difficult people?

title: Research Assistant Interview

Interview Descriptions: The interview process was straightforward - I received an email inviting me for an interview about two weeks after my submission of my application. My interview consisted of Microsoft Word and Excel online proficiency tests (which were more difficult than you would think), a brief interview with an HR Representative, and finally a longer (but less formal) interview with the team leaders of the program to which I applied.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions:
What a long process. I first spoke with the recruiter on the phone in a very brief mini-phone interview confirming the salary and interest/ understanding of the role about 2 weeks after applying online.

I then was invited for an interview via email the following day, scheduled for a week later. I went in and met with the hiring manager. The staff are very friendly and the work they do is very interesting.

I felt that the interview had gone really well and I was granted a second interview a week and a half later. The interview was requested on a Tuesday for the following day, Wednesday. There was limited notice and not much room to change the date and time. I met with four people, including a second interview with the hiring manager. Each interview went really well and I was confident at the end I had a great shot at the position. At the conclusion, I was told it was between myself and one other person and a decision would be made the following day, but I wouldn't know for 1-2 weeks. 

After 2 weeks, I contacted the appropriate people and was informed I was not selected. I was then informed of a second position opening and was asked to apply, as I did make a good impression and a future at IOM was something they saw for me. I applied and was asked to wait 1 week. After 1 week, I was told no decision was made on the position, but was asked to come in with very short notice to meet three more people for 2 other possible RA positions available. I rearranged my schedule and went in to meet the other team members. With much delayed notification and waiting, I did not get 2/3 of the jobs I was then being considered for and the 3rd was waiting on funding. 

As you can see it was quite an ordeal and required lots of waiting and patience. I followed up for feedback as I really would like to learn from this experience - i,e, what I was missing in experience and/ or why I wasn't selected. At this point, I have been offered a job at another company, but thought I would share my experience in case anyone else is patiently waiting replies. 

It was quite lovely to meet with the staff, they are very smart and driven people. I do feel I made a large time commitment with lot's of positive feedback followed by disappointment that I did not get the positions discussed. I had such a positive experience when at the interviews, but in the end I felt that my time was not a concern and it's left me feeling the experience was more negative. 

The interviews were all pretty standard. More conversational than question/ answer.
Interview Questions: What is the biggest problem in clinical research?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences (Washington, DC) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and got a call about 2 weeks later. The recruiter asked me 2 behavioral questions and my availability. Few days later she sent an email asking me to come for an interview. I interviewed with the project supervisor who was very nice. After that, I got an email 2 weeks later asking for email references. They got in touch with my references the same day, and I got the offer for the job the following day. Then I received a package in the mail with an official letter, documentation, and some cool NAS gear.
Interview Questions: The questions were mostly behavioral. How do you work with people? Tell me an example of how the qualities on your cover letter will make you succeed in the position? She also asked me about one of the things I put on my resume which was an honors program I was in. One very important thing, HAVE QUESTIONS ready. The lady who interviewed me didn't think 4 questions were enough.

title: Development Associate Interview

Said second round of interview callings will begin the last week of this month from HR. Waiting for phone call and will follow up either today or tomorrow about the status.

title: Senior Program Assistant Interview

Interview Descriptions: This was an internal hire. Sometimes, it works to one's benefit to follow-up with Human Resources because I discovered they did NOT forward my application as they said they would.  Be thorough in your follow-up when dealing with HR.
Interview Questions: Why should I hire you for this position?

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences (Washington, DC) in Jun 2013
Interview Descriptions: Initial phone interview with HR, followed by meeting with core team members and tour of facility.  Interview questions included prior experience and the format was a group panel.  Atmosphere was relatively relaxed and informal.
Interview Questions: Prior experience

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences (Washington, DC) in Mar 2013
Interview Descriptions: Two interviews, very thorough process but relaxed and not designed to intimidate. Everyone was very generous with their time and genuinely interested to both learn about me and share their experience working at NAS.
Interview Questions: What do I expect to gain from the position?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences
Interview Descriptions: Getting the interview was the hard part. The actual interview wasn't so bad, but the job descriptions  can be really vague when it comes to what you'll actually be doing. I think it would be easier to find great candidates if there weren't such generic postings for the jobs. A lot of the people I know with the same title do totally different things. It totally depends on what your actually working group does.
Interview Questions: I felt like most of the interview questions were pretty standard. There wasn't one in particular that threw me off.

title: Senior Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences (Washington, DC) in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions: There was an initial and brief phone interview with a human resources representative. The callback interview was at facilities. This consisted of three parts: an interview with a human resources representative (20 minutes), a timed computer aptitude test (MS Office Suite; 10-15 minutes), and lastly an interview by the sectional supervisor (20 minutes).
Interview Questions:
Describe your professional background.
What from your past professional experiences qualifies you for this position?
Describe your interest in this position.
Describe your interest in this organization and specific office.

title: Program Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at National Academy of Sciences (Washington, DC) in Feb 2011
Interview Descriptions: The HR department contacted me to arrange an interview. It was easy to communicate with HR and get information. Salary negotiations were done through the recruiter which was strange. The interview process varies depending on the hiring manager. Some ask challenging questions, but most are interviews to get to know you. If you convey confidence and talk about your experiences and how they fit in with the organization you should be good.
Interview Questions: None. Basic interview questions, tell me about your work experience.
